Past Session Information: Past session- Diagnostic assessment for eating disorder
Presenting Complaints (Symptoms):
1. Irresistible craving for food
2. Repeated bouts of overeating
3. Episodes of self-induced vomiting
4. Preoccupation with control of body weight
Associated disturbance- Reduced self-confidence
History: Present history: Episodes of bulimia; Onset- Chronic; Course- Continuous; Past history: Index patient was 10 years old when her parents got divorced. She continued living with her mother. Her parents got remarried after 2 years. Patient was more close to her father and her paternal grandmother. She moved to a different town after her mother remarried which led to a change in her school from a public to a private one. Patient couldn't fit well in the pre-existing social groups in her new school. She also went through critical remarks from her mother about her body and eating habits. She also pressurised her to fit in the social circle in her new school. It was during her 9th std, when she was around 14 years, that she first engaged in restricted food intake. She also learnt about self-induced vomiting as an option to control body weight and started practicing that. Every time she felt stressed or had argument with her mother, her binge eating and purging episodes would increase; Family history: Patient's parents got divorced when she was 10years old. She lived with her mother and continued meeting her father fairly often. Her mother remarried after 2 years and took a second divorce when patient was 17 years old. Patient has a step sister from her mother's second marriage. She shares a strained relationship with her mother.
Current Mental Status Examination: General Behavior: Patient was conscious and touch with her surroundings. She was cooperative and rapport could be established; Mood- Dysphoric; Affect: Restricted; Insight: Grade 5
Issues discussed in Current Session:
1. Major focus on first and most recent episode
2. Exploration of childhood experiences, especially with parents
3. Understanding support system(s) patient relied on in the past
4. Understanding reaction patterns to stress
Reflections by the therapist: Patient was cordial and rapport could be easily established. She came with a rough idea of the disorder and was psychoeducated. She comprehended the information well. Reflective listening was used by paraphrasing and summarising which helped in improving the communication. Her complaints were understood more in terms of a social or interpersonal context.
